head.title: Not All Food Can Be Local

hedline.hl1: Not All Food Can Be Local

block.p: In ''Preserving Fossil Fuels and Nearby Farmland by Eating Locally,'' April 25, Jessica Prentice has it right: ''Eating locally is an interesting exercise.'' But if we are truly interested in a sustainable food system, we must consider the producer's point of view as well as the consumer's.

From the producer's perspective, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, olive oil and wine are products that could not survive if they had to depend on local-only consumption. ''Locavores'' should understand that there's a difference between indulging in tasteless midwinter raspberries and supporting the efforts of indigenous farmers whose livings depend on offering their unique products to a global market.

In ''Preserving Fossil Fuels and Nearby Farmland by Eating Locally,'' April 25, Jessica Prentice has it right: ''Eating locally is an interesting exercise.'' But if we are truly interested in a sustainable food system, we must consider the producer's point of view as well as the consumer's.

From the producer's perspective, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, olive oil and wine are products that could not survive if they had to depend on local-only consumption. ''Locavores'' should understand that there's a difference between indulging in tasteless midwinter raspberries and supporting the efforts of indigenous farmers whose livings depend on offering their unique products to a global market.

Removing jet fuel from the food chain is good for both the food and the planet, but allowing biodiversity to wither through benign neglect is not. To achieve a truly sustainable food system we must support both our own local agriculture and everyone else's.
The author is a co-leader of Slow Food NYC.
